The block is initially at rest and is placed on the moving plate. The plate has a mass M = 2m and the block has a mass m. The block and the plate will have different accelerations due to the frictional forces acting on them. Let the acceleration of the block be a2 and the acceleration of the plate be a1.
For the block, the only force acting on it is the frictional force μ1mg (since the block does not leave the plate, the normal force is mg). Using Newton's second law, μ1mg = ma2 implies a2 = μ1g.

For the plate, the forces acting on it are the frictional force μ1mg (opposite to its motion) and the frictional force μ2(M + m)g (where μ2 is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the plate and the horizontal surface). Using Newton's second law, μ1mg - μ2(M + m)g = Ma1 implies μ1mg - 3μ2mg = 2ma1, which simplifies to a1 = (μ1g - 3μ2g)/2.

The block and the plate will reach the same velocity when the block catches up with the plate. The velocity of the block as a function of time is given by the area under the velocity-time graph in Figure B. Since the graph is not provided, we assume the form of the velocity-time graph is linear and the velocity of the block as a function of time is vb(t) = μ1gt.

The velocity of the plate as a function of time is vp(t) = v0 + a1t, where v0 is the initial velocity of the plate. However, since the initial velocity of the plate is not given and we are only interested in the relative motion, we can use the fact that the block and the plate will have the same velocity at some time t.

The relative velocity is vb - vp = μ1gt - (v0 + a1t). Since the block and the plate reach the same velocity, μ1gt = v0 + a1t. The initial velocity of the plate v0 is not given, but we can find a1 in terms of μ1 and μ2 from the equation a1 = (μ1g - 3μ2g)/2.
